featured.label: Flagship Project
featured.title: TRANSACT: Transparency in Action
featured.tagline: Evaluating FOI implementation through field experiments and citizen science
featured.description: TRANSACT is a large-scale research project that measures the gap between formal adoption of Freedom of Information laws and their actual implementation. Using a controlled experimental protocol, we sent FOI requests to all 581 municipalities in Belgium using five different requester profiles — from ordinary citizens to university professors and civil society organisations. Each municipality was randomly assigned one treatment, stratified by region and population size. Responses were coded on a five-point scale from no reply to complete disclosure.

grid.title: Transparencia.be Analysis
grid.description: Computational text analysis of 4,266 citizen FOI requests submitted through Belgium's national transparency platform over 10 years (2016–2025). We built a full NLP pipeline including HTML cleaning, tokenisation, TF-IDF filtering, and lemmatisation, followed by LDA topic modeling (K=6) and sentiment analysis using the FEEL lexicon for French. Multinomial logistic regression predicts outcomes as a function of topic, accountability-seeking potential, sentiment, and request complexity.

grid.title: FOI-RESPOND
grid.description: A proposed 36-month co-research project with Anticor Belgique (operator of Transparencia.be), submitted to the INNOVIRIS Co-Create 2026 call. The project aims to understand and improve FOI responsiveness in the Brussels-Capital Region through qualitative investigation with 15–20 public official interviews, citizen focus groups, and an action-research component. Requested budget: €360,000.

grid.title: Gender & FOI
grid.description: Investigating whether different genders have different FOI information needs and whether administrations respond differently based on the requester’s gender. Analysis of 4,266 requests from Transparencia.be with gender derived from first-name categorisation. A collaboration between Julia Trautendorfer (JKU Linz), Enrico Quaglia (Genoa/CEPAP), Giovanni Esposito (ULB), and Vincent Mabillard (ULB).

grid.title: International Replication
grid.description: Extending the TRANSACT methodology beyond Belgium to build comparative evidence on FOI implementation worldwide. Current expansion targets: Switzerland (cantonal and municipal FOI across the federal system), Romania (post-transition transparency contexts), South Africa (via Wits University, Global South perspective), and Uganda (via Makerere University, East African context).
